timeline.message:
Enable SSLAlertEvent storage on SSLFDProxy

Storing events on a SSLFDProxy object requires:

 - A place to put them (both inbound and outbound),
 - A way of tracking how many we've processed,
 - A way of giving the SSLFDProxy reference to NSS (a GlobalRefProxy).

Unlike the client certificate callback (where we can directly pass the
CERTCertificate pointer and assume it is valid for the entire lifetime
of the SSLFDProxy), we have to have this global state in order to
interact with Java-owned objects.

We introduce helper functions for accessing and creating all
event-related members and add the underlying callbacks one would use to
trigger them. In the future, other callbacks could be written that
trigger an event (similar to the existing SSLSocket code); this isn't
suitable for use in an SSLEngine however.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Enable attaching SSL Alert capturing listeners

This enables logging of the SSLAlerts sent and received by a SSLFDProxy
instance using the callbacks provided SSLFDProxy.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Test new SSL alert logging functionality

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

@edewata Is there a better option here?
I want a data structure that let's me:

Track my position in the list
Push new elements
Know when a new one has been seen
But also lets me access previous elements if I need to.

Up until the last requirement, that's kinda looking like a stock queue (and calling .pop() and .push(...)) but...
